title: 112_hr692
content: The "Nuclear Family Priority Act" changes family-sponsored immigrant categories to prioritize spouses and children of permanent resident aliens for visa allocation within specified worldwide levels. SEC. 3 of the "Nuclear Family Priority Act" amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to change the worldwide level of family-sponsored immigrants. The amendment removes certain paragraphs and adjusts the calculation for the number of family-sponsored immigrants. SEC. 4 includes conforming amendments. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to allocate 75 percent of family-sponsored immigrant visas without per country limitations, with the remaining 25 percent reserved for countries under subsection (e). The Immigration and Nationality Act allocates 75 percent of family-sponsored immigrant visas without per country limitations, with the remaining 25 percent reserved for countries under subsection (e), subject to specific conditions. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to determine whether certain aliens are children and to update the procedure for granting immigrant status. The Immigration and Nationality Act (8 U.S.C. 1154) is amended to update the procedure for granting immigrant status, specifically regarding classification by relationship and preference status for individuals under 21 years of age. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to update procedures for granting immigrant status, including waivers of inadmissibility and conditional permanent resident status for certain alien spouses and children. Classes of deportable aliens are also revised. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to update procedures for granting immigrant status, including waivers of inadmissibility and revising classes of deportable aliens. Specifically, the amendment involves changing the reference from "203(a)(2)" to "203(a)". SEC. 5. Nonimmigrant status for alien parent of adult United States citizens. Nonimmigrant status for alien parent of adult United States citizens is granted under new amendments to the Immigration and Nationality Act. The parent must have a citizen child who is at least 21 years old, and the initial authorized admission period is 5 years, extendable as long as the child resides in the United States. The nonimmigrant described in section 101(a)(15)(W) is not allowed to work in the US and is not eligible for any public benefits. The US citizen child must support the nonimmigrant, and the nonimmigrant must have health insurance arranged by the child at no cost. The amendments made by this Act will take effect on the first day of the second fiscal year after enactment, with certain restrictions on petitions and visa applications under family-sponsored immigrant categories.
